choices.D: A server pool can have the same attributes defined for different policies in the policy set, when user-defined policy management is used.
choices.C: A server pool can have different attributes defined for different policies in the policy set, when user-defined policy management is used.
choices.A: All server pools in a cluster are controlled by the policy set, when user-defined policy management is used.
choices.E: Servers in a server pool outside the control of the policy set are never affected by policy changes, when user-defined policy management is used.
choices.B: Clusterware administrators cannot directly modify the policy set when Quality of Service (QoS) Management is used.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about the administration and use of policy sets in Oracle 19c Clusterware? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACE
A: true
Unmanaged server pools are not controlled by the policy set. With administrator-managed clusters, you manually configure how the cluster resources are deployed and where the workload is managed. Therefore, servers in a server pool that is not managed by a policy set are unaffected by policy changes because the policy set only governs the behavior of managed pools.
C: true
 Specifically, when using Oracle Database QoS Management, server pools are categorized by setting server pool directive overrides, and the use of CRSCTL commands using the policy and policyset nouns are disabled
E: true
Can have different attributes in different policies
For example, the MIN_SIZE and MAX_SIZE attributes of a server pool can be modified for different policies within a policy set to accommodate different application demands at different times

Selected Answer: CDE
A I think is false because Generic Server pool is created by default and it's not policy-managed.
B: I think is false because QoS influence the configuration based on performance objectives but administrator may be able to modify

questions.question_text:
Disk group DGRP1 has these attributes:
1. Normal redundancy
2. Two failure groups FG1 and FG2 with two disks each
3. Compatibility settings set to 19.0
The FG1 failure group goes offline due to hardware failure.
Which two statements are true? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
"New allocation units are mirrored in the FG2 failure group until FG1 is restored and the disk group resynchronized." This statement is true.
Oracle ASM will allocate new extents in a mirrored fashion to the remaining online failure groups. In this case, since only FG2 is online, the new allocation units will be mirrored in FG2.
"The redundancy is lowered until the FG1 fail group is restored and the disk group resynchronized." This statement is true.
When a failure group is offline, the disk group's data is still available and the disk group remains mounted. However, redundancy is reduced because there is one less copy of the data.
Oracle ASM will resynchronize the data on the disks of FG1 when they are brought back online. Until the resynchronization is complete, redundancy is reduced.

Selected Answer: AD
A is true 
D could be true if the failure of FG1 results in data unavailability or loss that impacts ongoing transactions. However, Oracle ASM is designed to maintain data availability and integrity even in the event of failures. Transactions may experience temporary interruptions or delays, but they typically do not fail outright unless the failure severely impacts data access.

B is false because In Oracle ASM, the redundancy level of a disk group is not lowered during a failure. Instead, Oracle ASM dynamically adjusts data allocation and mirroring to maintain redundancy even in the presence of failures.

C is false because . Oracle ASM continues to mirror new allocation units across the remaining operational failure group (FG2) to maintain redundancy and data availability. Tracking changes to allocation units is part of ASM's internal management but does not affect the mirroring of new data.

choices.A: New allocation units are mirrored in the FG2 failure group until FG1 is restored and the disk group resynchronized.
choices.B: The redundancy is lowered until the FG1 failgroup is restored and the disk group resynchronized.
choices.D: Transactions on database objects stored in tablespaces in the DGRP1 disk group fail.
choices.C: New allocation units are not mirrored but changes to allocation units are tracked in the FG2 failure group.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
I think A E correct answer.

questions.question_text:
You administer a RAC database that currently runs on a four-node cluster but which has three instances.
Which two statements are always true about redo logs for this RAC database? (Choose two.)

choices.A: A thread of redo must be created before starting a fourth instance if a thread is not already available.
choices.D: A redo log group added using ALTER DATABASE ADD LOGFILE without the INSTANCE clause is added to each instance.
choices.B: A thread of redo is automatically dropped when an instance is removed from a RAC database by using SRVCTL.
choices.E: A thread of redo must contain at least two log groups before it can be enabled.
choices.C: All the instances must have the same number of redo log groups and each group must have the same number of redo log members.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
C => Oracle Documentation says: "From any node that you are not deleting, run the following command from the Grid_home/bin directory as root to delete the node from the cluster:
# crsctl delete node -n node_to_be_deleted"

E => Oracle Documentation says: " Disable the Oracle Clusterware applications and daemons running on the node. Run the rootcrs.pl script as root from the Grid_home/crs/install directory on the node to be deleted, as follows: 
# ./rootcrs.pl -deconfig -force 
If you are deleting multiple nodes, then run the rootcrs.pl script on each node that you are deleting."
C. Run the crsctl delete node -n host04 command as root on host01, or on either host02 or host03. E. Run the rootcrs.pl -deconfig -force command as root on host04.

choices.B: Run the crsctl delete node -n host04 command as root on host04.
choices.A: Run the crsctl unpin css - host04 command as root on host01, or on either host02 or host03.
choices.C: Run the crsctl delete node -n host04 command as root on host01, or on either host02 or host03.
choices.E: Run the rootcrs.pl -deconfig -force command as root on host04.
choices.F: Run the rootcrs.pl -deconfig -force command as root on host01, or on either host02 or host03.
choices.D: Run the crsct1 unpin css - host04 command as root on host04.

questions.question_text: Which two steps must always be performed to delete node host04 from an Oracle 19c Clusterware cluster that does not use Grid Naming Service (GNS)? (Choose two.)
Which three statements are true about services and load balancing for Oracle 19c clients connecting to Oracle 19c RAC database instances? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ADE
B: false, not node listener, should be SCAN listener to perform redirection.
C: false, both for client and listener (client/server side )

Selected Answer: ACE
Tricky question, but looks like ACE:

If you configured SCAN for connection requests, then client-side load balancing is not relevant for those clients that support SCAN access. With that in mind, we can have load balancing client-side OR load balancing server-side, not both.

If you are using clients that do not support SCAN (for example, the client version is pre-Oracle Database 11g release 2 (11.2)), then, to use SCAN you must change the client tnsnames.ora to include the SCAN VIPs, and set LOAD_BALANCE=ON to balance requests across the VIPs. 

Ref:https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/racad/workload-management-with-dynamic-database-services.html#GUID-10F7892A-92DD-482C-8D68-AE80CE956010

comments.content: C and E negate each other.

choices.C: Load balancing can be done by the client or the listener, but not both, for any one connection request.
choices.B: In server-side load balancing, node listener redirects the client to another node listener for connection to an instance.
choices.E: Load balancing can be done by the client, the listener, or both, for any one connection request.
choices.D: Client-side connect-time load balancing can balance connection requests across SCAN listeners.
choices.A: Services support the balancing of client connections across RAC database instances.
